title: Kiersten Bicmore‚Äôs CV
text:
Student at Brigham Young University - Idaho

bic19001@byui.edu | LinkedIn Page



I am currently a student attending Brigham Young University - Idaho majoring in Professional Studies with a minor in data science and a cluster in math.


I have had a few different kinds of work experience and the ability to learn new skills from each position. Some of these skills include customer service, training new employees, prepping ingredients to create orders to customer specifications, taking inventory and recording numbers, and researching information to report. Different experiences have given me useful skills to use in my daily life, one skill being communication gained from speaking in front of large groups. I have grown to use both Adobe Photoshop and Microsoft Office products effectively and efficiently.




September 2019 - Current Brigham Young University ‚Äì Idaho
August 2017 - May 2019 Chattahoochee High School



Custodian March 2023 - July 2024 - Custodian - Cleaned several areas, including bathrooms and offices - Trainer - Explained daily procedure to new employees - Inventory/Stocker - Organized and took count of the number of items in each closet; stocked items that were running low
Sanitizer January 2022 - April 2022 - Sanitizer - Walked around sanitizing areas; cleaned any areas that were out of order/dirty - Inventory/Stocker - Organized and took count of the number of items in each closet; stocked items that were running low for the morning crew
Domino‚Äôs Pizza Customer Service Representative January 2021 - April 2021 - Cashier/Customer Service - Informed customers about different products, calculated purchase totals for customers and verified prices; addressed concerns and complaints with products - Food Prep - Stocked food supplies for pizza, sandwiches, and pasta, prepared food samples for customers, prepared meals for customer orders
Inventory/Reporter February 2020 - Spetember 2020 - Inventory/Reporter - Organized and took count of the number of items in each unit; reported said numbers and other information to employer - Starter - Arrived at storage units at planned time to work - Researcher - Researched prices of medical equipment and recorded numbers on Excel
Great Harvest Bread Company August 2018 - May 2019 - Cashier/Customer Service - Informed customers about different products, calculated purchase totals for customers and verified prices, gaining experience in customer interaction and clerical skills; addressed concerns and complaints with products - Trainer - Explained daily procedure to new employees - Closer ‚Äì Store facility maintenance - Food Prep ‚Äì Stocked food supplies for sandwiches, prepared food samples for customers, prepared meals for customer orders

title: Data Exploration 01
text:
A consumer watchdog group wants to see if Netflix has more movies for adults or children.
Using a dataset containing metadata for all of the movies Netflix had available on their platform in 2019, we‚Äôll use the MPAA movie rating system to determine if they are correct.

title: Data Exploration 01
text:
MPAA Movie Ratings:

G: All ages admitted.
PG: Some material may not be suitable for children.
PG-13: Some material may be inappropriate for children under 13.
R: Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian
NC-17: No One 17 and Under Admitted

Most people would consider G and PG as ratings suitable for children. However, not everyone would agree that a PG-13 movie is necssarily a children‚Äôs movie. It is up to you to decide how to handle this.

title: Data Exploration 01
text:
Part 1: Import Pandas
The pandas library is a python library used for data analysis and manipulation. It will provide the core functionality for most of what you do in the data exploration and preprocessing stages of most machine learning projects.
Please see this Getting Started Guide for information on the conventional way to import Pandas into your project, as well as other helpful tips for common Pandas tasks.

# Part 1: Enter the code below to import Pandas according to the
# conventional method.

import pandas as pd

title: Data Exploration 01
text:
Part 2: Load the data
The dataset for this exploration is stored at the following url:
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/byui-cse/cse450-course/master/data/netflix_titles.csv
There are lots of ways to load data into your workspace. The easiest way in this case is to ask Pandas to do it for you.

Initial Data Analysis
Once you‚Äôve loaded the data, it‚Äôs a good idea to poke around a little bit to find out what you‚Äôre dealing with.
Some questions you might ask include:

What does the data look like?
What kind of data is in each column?
Do any of the columns have missing values?


# Part 2: Load the dataset into a Pandas dataframe.

netflix = pd.read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/byui-cse/cse450-course/master/data/netflix_titles.csv')


# Then, explore the data by seeing what the first few rows look like.

netflix.head(3)

title: Data Exploration 01
text:
Part 3: Filter the Data
Since we‚Äôre just interested in movies, we‚Äôll need to filter out anything that isn‚Äôt a movie for our analysis. The type feature contains this information.
Once we have the subset, we should see how many rows it contains. There are a variety of ways to get the length of a data frame.

# Use pandas's filtering abilitites to select the subset of data
# that represents movies, then calculate how many rows are in the filtered data.

movie = netflix[ netflix['type'] == 'Movie']
len(movie)

4265



MPAA Ratings
Now that we have only movies, let‚Äôs get a quick count of the values being used in the rating feature.

# Determine the number of records for each value of the "rating" feature.
# Remember to count the values in your subset only, not in the original dataframe.

movie['rating'].value_counts()

dtype: int64




More Filtering
There are apparently some ‚Äúmade for TV‚Äù movies in the list that don‚Äôt fit the MPAA rating scheme.
Let‚Äôs filter some more to just see movies rated with the standard MPAA ratings of G, PG, PG-13, R, and NC-17.

# Filter the list of movies to select a new subset containing only movies with
# a standard MPAA rating. Calculate how many rows are in this new set, and
# then see which ratings appear most often.

mpaa_ratings = ['G', 'PG', 'PG-13', 'R', 'NC-17']
mpaa_movies = movie[ movie['rating'].isin(mpaa_ratings) ]
mpaa_movies['rating'].value_counts()

title: Data Exploration 01
text:
Part 4: Visualization
Now that we have explored and preprocessed our data, let‚Äôs create a visualization to summarize our findings.

Exploration vs Presentation
Broadly speaking, there are two types of visualizations: * Barebones visualizations you might use to get a quick, visual understanding of the data while you‚Äôre trying to decide how it all fits together. * Presentation-quality visualizations that you would include in a report or presentation for management or other stakeholders.


Visualization Tools
There are many different visualization tools availble. In the sections below, we‚Äôll explore the three most common. Each of these libraries has strengths and weaknesses.
It is probably a good idea for you to become familiar with each one, and then become proficient at whichever one you like the best.


Altair
The Altair visualization library provides a large variety of very easy to use statistical charting tools.
Altair uses a declarative language to build up charts piece by piece.
Assume we have a pandas dataframe called employees, with three columns: name, job, salary.
# Make a box plot style categorical plot showing the distribution of salaries for each job:
alt.Chart(employees).mark_boxplot().encode(
    x='job',
    y='salary'
)

# Make a box plot style categorical plot, and customize the results
alt.Chart(employees).mark_boxplot().encode(
    alt.X('job', title='Job title'),
    alt.Y('salary', title='Annual salary in thousands of $USD')
).properties(
  title='Salaries by Job Title'
)
Like with Pandas, there is a conventional way to import Altair into your projects.

# Import the Altair library the conventional way.

import altair as alt

Let‚Äôs create a barchart showing the count of each movie rating by using Altair‚Äôs aggregation capabilities.
In this example, we see the x axis being set to a feature called a, and the y axis set to the average() of a feature called b.
In our case, we want the x axis to be set to rating and the y axis to be the count() of rating.

# Use Altair to create a bar chart comparing the count of each movie rating

alt.Chart(mpaa_movies).mark_bar().encode(
    x='rating',
    y='count(rating)')









Seaborn
While Altair uses a ‚Äúdeclarative‚Äù syntax for building charts piece by piece, the Seaborn library provides a large variety of pre-made charts for common statistical needs.
These charts are divided into different categories. Each category has a high-level interface you can use for simplicity, and then a specific function for each chart that you can use if you need more control over how the chart looks.
Seaborn uses matplotlib for its drawing, and the chart-specific functions each return a matplitlib axes object if you need additional customization.
For example, there are several different types of categorical plots in seaborn: bar plots, box plots, point plots, count plots, swarm plots, etc‚Ä¶
Each of these plots can be accessed using the catplot function.
Assume we have a pandas dataframe called employees, with three columns: name, job, salary.
# Make a box plot style categorical plot showing the distribution of salaries for each job:
sns.catplot(data=employees, x='job', y='salary', kind='box')

# Make a swarm plot style categorical plot
sns.catplot(data=employees, x='job', y='salary', kind='swarm')
Alternatively, you can use the plot specific functions to give yourself more control over the output by using matplotlib functions:
# Make a box plot style categorical plot, and customize the results
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.figure(figsize=(12, 9))
ax = sns.boxplot(data=employees, x='job', y='salary')
ax.set_title("Salaries by Job Title")
ax.set_ylabel("Annual salary in thousands of $USD")
ax.set_xlabel("Job title")
Like with Pandas, there is a conventional way to import Seaborn into your projects.
Optionally, you may wish to set some default chart aesthetics by setting the chart style.

# Import the seaborn library the conventional way. Then optionally configure
# the default chart style.

import seaborn as sns
sns.set()
sns.set_style('whitegrid')

Since the rating column uses categorical data, we need to use Seaborn‚Äôs categorical visualizations.
In particular, we want a ‚Äúcount plot‚Äù that will display a count of movie ratings.

# Use seaborn to create a count plot comparing the count of each movie rating

sns.catplot(data=mpaa_movies, x='rating', kind="count")










Pandas built-in plotting
In addition to libraries like Altair and Seaborn, Pandas has some built in charting functionality.
While not as sophisticated as some of the other options, it is often good enough for quick visualizations.
Just like with seaborn‚Äôs plotting functions, the pandas plotting functions return matplotlib axes objects, which can be further customized.
Assume we have a pandas dataframe called employees, with three columns: name, job, salary.
# Make a box plot style categorical plot showing the distribution of salaries for each job:
employees[ ['job','salary'] ].plot.box()

# Make a box plot style categorical plot, and customize the results
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.figure(figsize=(12, 9))
ax = employees[ ['job','salary'] ].plot().box()
ax.set_title("Salaries by Job Title")
ax.set_ylabel("Annual salary in thousands of $USD")
ax.set_xlabel("Job title")

# Use pandas' built in plotting functions to create a count plot comparing the count of each movie rating
# This will be a little trickier than the other libraries, but one hint is that the pandas value_counts() function
# actually returns a dataframe.

mpaa_movies['rating'].value_counts().plot.bar()

title: Data Exploration 01
text:
üåü Above and Beyond üåü
After reviewing your findings, the watchdog group would like some additional questions answered:

How are things affected if you include the ‚Äúmade for TV movies‚Äù that have been assigned TV ratings in your analysis, but still exclude unrated movies?
They would also like to see a separate report that includes only TV shows.
For an upcoming community meeting, the group would like to present a simple chart showing ‚ÄúFor Kids‚Äù and ‚ÄúFor Adults‚Äù categories. The easiest way to accomplish this would be to create a new column in your data frame that maps each rating to the appropriate ‚ÄúFor Kids‚Äù or ‚ÄúFor Adults‚Äù label, then create a new visualization based on that column.
